content:
ry 2
												Assuming you like the "South Park" television show, I'm Recommending the game "South Park:  The Stick of Truth."  It's essentially exactly like the show.  In the same vein, if you don't like the show, I wouldn't recommend the game.  That said, I have no idea how they got this game to market without some kind of Adult Only rating.  There's a LOT of really foul and disgusting stuff in it.  But, again, that's just like the show.Anyway, I got 30 hours of really good game play out of it with 100% Achievements (10 hours for Day 1, 8 hours each for Days 2 and 3, and another 4 hours getting my remaining Achievements during the "Day" after the game finishes).  So, by my dollar an hour standard metric, I'd say it's worth buying at anything under $30.I do have some issues with the game:- My biggest problem is the huge number of missable Achievements (by "missable," I mean that if you don't do certain things at certain times, the option to do so disappears forever and you miss Achievements).  This is extremely frustrating.- Even though you can save at any point, the saves only save back to the last checkpoint (which is usually very close to your current position (most likely when you entered the room)).  The problem with this is that you might have done a missable activity in that period between the checkpoint and your saving, think you've done what needs doing, and then lose it upon loading.  This happened to me with two separate Achievements.- Every time you start the game, you're treated to four non-skippable logo animations.  The only way to get rid of those is to rename four files.- The controls for magic (i.e., farting) are really confusing.  When you first get a "spell," you go through some training.  Yet the method you're trained to use is never used anywhere else in the game.  Along with that, the method you actually use is different depending on if you're in combat or not.  Also, in combat during the early part of the game, you're giving an option to use the F key to "cast" the "spell" with some of your weapons.  That flat out doesn't work.  Later in the game, the instruction changes to say to use the W key.  That works.Other than that, no issues.  The game is a lot of fun that follows the South Park theme perfectly.  Recommended for those who like the show.NOTE:  if you're the type of person who doesn't do Achievements, then the game will probably be far shorter for you.  I've seen posts saying the game only lasts 11 to 15 hours that way.  I have no idea why someone would spend good money on a game and then not complete it (even though they've reached the finish line).  But, if that applies to you, be aware of the duration difference.

content:
26, 2014
												If you don't enjoy South Park tv series, I'm sure you won't enjoy The Stick of Truth - as this game is being closer to a long episode from the show than to a cRPG. Battles are easy and the system is very simple, yet I wasn't bored, as enemies are so, uh, unusual you are waiting what kind of wacky attack they will use next.I used to watch South Park season 1 back in the... 1998? but didn't come back watching after that (if it was on some public channel I would, most likely), so going back to South Park and meeting all these new (to me) characters was an awesome experience. Especially when this "dungeons and dragons" story is just a kid's game of pretending to be wizards, warriors etc., with everyone being fully aware of that and throwing comments like "what's with this stupid turn-based system?" and more: farts are "magic", coffee is a "speed potion" etc. and I enjoyed this aspect of the game world a lot.There is only one thing I didn't like (besides it being so short, as I really wanted the game to last longer and was sad it's already over): some songs are recycled from the show and don't fit the theme, for example there is Lemmiwinks song, yet you are the "hero" now...? Same goes with abortion song mentioning "Christmas", which is out of place in the context of the game story.Anyway if you enjoy South Park, you should enjoy this game as well, despite its simplicity.

content:
4, 2014
												If you're a fan of South Park, purchasing this is a no-brainer. I'm so happy this game was as good as I hoped it would be and more. I used to play loads of turn-based RPGs back in the day but eventually became disinterested with them after a couple disappointing titles (Star Ocean 4, Tales of Vesperia and Final Corridor XIII), but Obsidian have created a combat system which is both simple and yet has complexities which fits perfectly with Trey Parker and Matt Stone's hilarious writing and sense of humour. At several points during this game I had to stop playing because I was laughing so hard.Being an Obsidian game, I was expecting a ton of bugs but surprisingly enough there were very few (mainly some patch equipping and stuck in cutscenes issues). I'm glad they took time to hire a competent QA department this time round as I think the amount of bugs present in Fallout: New Vegas upon release unfortunately impacted the reception of a game which ultimately was better than Fallout 3 in many ways.The Stick of Truth is one of those games where you can't talk about it in much detail with someone who is a fan of South Park but has yet to play it, because you don't want to spoil the sheer enjoyment they'll have from playing this game. You're actually excited for them to play and experience it for themselves - it's that ♥♥♥♥ing good.

ry 2
												Assuming you like the "South Park" television show, I'm Recommending the game "South Park:  The Stick of Truth."  It's essentially exactly like the show.  In the same vein, if you don't like the show, I wouldn't recommend the game.  That said, I have no idea how they got this game to market without some kind of Adult Only rating.  There's a LOT of really foul and disgusting stuff in it.  But, again, that's just like the show.Anyway, I got 30 hours of really good game play out of it with 100% Achievements (10 hours for Day 1, 8 hours each for Days 2 and 3, and another 4 hours getting my remaining Achievements during the "Day" after the game finishes).  So, by my dollar an hour standard metric, I'd say it's worth buying at anything under $30.I do have some issues with the game:- My biggest problem is the huge number of missable Achievements (by "missable," I mean that if you don't do certain things at certain times, the option to do so disappears forever and you miss Achievements).  This is extremely frustrating.- Even though you can save at any point, the saves only save back to the last checkpoint (which is usually very close to your current position (most likely when you entered the room)).  The problem with this is that you might have done a missable activity in that period between the checkpoint and your saving, think you've done what needs doing, and then lose it upon loading.  This happened to me with two separate Achievements.- Every time you start the game, you're treated to four non-skippable logo animations.  The only way to get rid of those is to rename four files.- The controls for magic (i.e., farting) are really confusing.  When you first get a "spell," you go through some training.  Yet the method you're trained to use is never used anywhere else in the game.  Along with that, the method you actually use is different depending on if you're in combat or not.  Also, in combat during the early part of the game, you're giving an option to use the F key to "cast" the "spell" with some of your weapons.  That flat out doesn't work.  Later in the game, the instruction changes to say to use the W key.  That works.Other than that, no issues.  The game is a lot of fun that follows the South Park theme perfectly.  Recommended for those who like the show.NOTE:  if you're the type of person who doesn't do Achievements, then the game will probably be far shorter for you.  I've seen posts saying the game only lasts 11 to 15 hours that way.  I have no idea why someone would spend good money on a game and then not complete it (even though they've reached the finish line).  But, if that applies to you, be aware of the duration difference.

content:
8, 2016
												An exciting discovery, South Park: The Stick of Truth is actually a very good RPG.  The story is, to put it bluntly, fantastic as it feels like I played a fourteen hour South Park episode where I was starring as a fellow eight year old who has moved to the small town.  The mechanics are relatively simple but entertaining and engaging enough that they didn't feel like a negative aspect at any point in the game.The game is packed full of adventures that are new and yet familiar for any fans, or even casual watchers, of South Park.  You'll be running around all over South Park and the surrounding area and getting into trouble with all of your favorite characters throughout.  I haven't watched as much of the show as I would like though the person I was playing it with is a huge fan and we both laughed our asses off through the entirety of it all the same.  It even led to her bringing up clips of what certain items and locations were in reference to which made the game all that much more enjoyable.The combat mechanics are similar to what I remember of Mario RPG in that every character has a variety of abilities that require pressing buttons at the right time or rotating the stick to get the full effect.  It kept combat interesting and engaging even with the relatively simple system.  The item system was fun as you find the most obnoxious weapons and gear and you can customize them with "strap-ons" that you find.I had twice the blast I was expecting from this game and I was expecting a good game.  I highly recommend this game to RPG gamers, South Park fans, and anyone looking for an extremely inappropriate adventure involving elves, nazis, aliens, and giant fetuses.  Give it a go and you won't be disappointed!

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
12, 2014
												In this day and age, the standard retail game costs around $60, and provides either 1-2 hours of gameplay, or a large amount of gameplay, with no replay value at all . South Park: The Stick of Truth is a funny, well made game that fits snuggly inbetween both examples above.  I finished the game after about 10 hours of playing, which is very respectable, and provides you with juuuust enough that, perhaps later on, you'll pick up a mouse and keyboard (Or controller) and try it again. The dialogue is hilarious, the gameplay is good, and Mr. Slave's... "storage" is scary. You can meet all your more known South Park characters, like Randy Marsh, Mr. Hankey, The Underpants Gnomes... Jesus... But its not necessary to do so, and you can just go along the story without giving a damn. I did not stray from the main quest, and to reach 10 hours with minimal sidequest completion is great. You don't have to go into places you don't want to, either. I know you can enter the sewers, but I decided not to unless the game forced me, after a long history of playing games with forced sewer gameplay. I was quite happy that I didn't have to go at all. As a result, I didn't meet The Christmas Poo, but I could live with that.The idea of a silent protagonist was obviously going to be a difficult thing to pull off, and South Park Studios and Obsidian Entertainment have pulled it off successfully. So congratulations to them. One thing I was unhappy with was the abilities, and how the were performed. almost everything involved mashing buttons on the keyboard or mouse. Wanted to poop? Mash a button. Want to use Jimmys abilities? Mash a button. Want Cartman to fat? Mash a button. It was very tedious and something I never really wanted to do after a while - But in order to win against many opponents, you needed to either A: mash these buttons, or B: use the normal attack, which did absolutely pitiful amounts of damage lategame. If you resorted to option B, you STILL have to press buttons, only this time, instead of mashing, it was timed with little "Ding" sounds, and a little flashing light. After a while, you could play the game with your eyes closed. In fact, to test this, I beat the final boss with my eyes closed (Except for the finale, which isn't really a battle. But I won't spoil it). Is the game good? I'd say so.Is it replayable? Maybe after a while.Do I recommend it? Well, if you don't mind mashing singular buttons, which are being timed against you, and are occaisionally difficult to pull off (such as creating ♥♥♥♥ Nuggets), then I guess its worth the money.

content:
6, 2014
												South Park was and remains the major cartoon serial for the game industry — though we seldom reflect on it. The Stick of Truth — not simply game according to the license: Parker and Stone personally participated in development, and the plan was realized by people who made Fallout: The New Vegas, and even earlier in Black Isle did the best role-playing games of the 90th. Unfortunately, even the best and the most experienced can be fond of own memoirs too. That, actually, also occurred. Authors will consistently see off us on all key and well familiar milestones of history of one mad city. Everything begins with a parable about an anal probe then before a look of players with whistle kalsonny gnomes, children Gotha, a Christmas ♥♥♥♥ Mr. Henki, Al Gore and his "Chelmedvedosvin", the Canadian sodomites, the zombie, Polotenchik and someone's huge hairy scrotum are carried by. To whom didn't get leading roles — are present at episodes, in the form of scenery or, at the worst, in the form of a dancing mug on the loading screen. The Stick of Truth hardly can be considered as independent chapter of South Park — it is rather interactive exhibition of achievements of the series, hardly squeezed in a framework of a conditional Japanese role-playing game from the 90th. The character with the workmate (one of heroes of series) goes on narrow paths of the city the South Park, is got involved in casual skirmishes, looks for the hidden treasures, puts on belongings and step by step fights with everyone. The Stick of Truth remains quite long game — at least for three-four evenings. This circumstance can become for someone critical: those who treats "South park" without awe, for certain will be tired of frequent and too easy fights, the bulky interface and similar awkwardness. And even the most devoted fans can get tired from terrible number of self-repetitions. (This my opinion and it can not coincide with yours).

												South Park: The Stick is Truth is no doubt a fantastic video-game adaptation, and I can heartily recommend this to any South Park fan. The gameplay is, sadly, far too easy and at times poorly explained, but it is most definitely a joy to play. Though not very lengthy, roughly 12 hours, it is from start to finish fantastic. Again, the one glaring issue I had came down to the almost utter lack of difficulty (And I then recommend anyone to put it on "Hardcore" from the start, sadly that is still far too easy) but the amazingly true-to-South-Park style more than makes up for that, with fantastic combat variety. A light and yet highly entertaining RPG that feels and plays like an extended South Park episode. Simply can't recommend it enough.Full review:

content:
4, 2014
												This game is simply amazing. Most tie in games are terrible and made only to make money or cash in on something that is popular at the moment.  Trey and Matt, along with Obsidian Ent. have crafted a wonderful game that looks and feels like South Park, on top of being very fun to play.This has been a dream type game for me over the years, something I would create in Game Dev Tycoon... take my favorite rpg developers and stick them with working with the south park writers on a south park RPG. It looks and feels like the damn tv show for crying out loud! Obsidian has done it again, managed to keep me glued to the monitor hours into the night. I have never laughed anywhere close to this much during a game, it is laugh out loud hilarious and will have you on the floor laughing non stop.There could be more pc settings and it could use a little balance in difficulty but those are the only negatives I can think of. The combat is fun, the story and writing is top notch, as is the atmosphere and the controls. They could have done a crap game and made money with the South Park license but instead the writers and Obsidian have put there heart and soul into this game.If you are a South Park fan or an Obsidian fan like me, don't even think twice go and buy this game ASAP. If you are on the fence about this game go read Giantbombs revierw (5/5), PC gamers review or even go watch Total Biscuits WTF is South Park vide on youtube, agree with those the most so far. Only 3-4 hours into it so far but boy have I had a blast! Cartman and all you're favorite south park characters are here as you (The new Kid in town) go on adventures while laughing your ♥♥♥ off. MUST OWN game, Obsidian and Trey/Matt deserve a pat on the back for a job well done. You can tell it was made with a ton of love and not just as a money cash in.

												Morgan Freeman's explanation:"You must understand that there is more to the hype for a proper South Park game than just the hopes and dreams of fans. The core concept of licensed video games hasn't gone well over the years for South Park, with the most successful titles being lousy 5 dollar Iphone minigames. The Stick of Truth did more than capture the feel of the iconic adult cartoon. It crossed the boundaries that we never thought that Parker and Stone had the courige to cross. But it was still only a mere baby step in what was to come. This game shall prepare you well for the next long journey of comedy."

content:
y 4, 2015
												South Park: The Stick of Truth is a brilliant hilarious game, That brings the crude humour of South Park and mixes it with solid Turn Based Combat.One of the funnest gaming experiences I had in 2014.Pros+Hilarious story, with loads of references to the show that fans of south park will love.+Good amount of customization.+Loads of unique levels and areas keep the gaming feeling fresh.+Lots of favourite characters from the show voiced by the real actors.=Combat is solid, however as the game progresses I feel like you become hugely over powered by the end.Cons-For an RPG, the game is very short. Completed it in a litte over 12 hours.-Would of liked to have seen more sidequests to give it more longevity.Final thoughtsAll in all, this is a very solid game that fans of the show should not miss. However if you are not a fan of the show or do not enjoy crude humour then this game is not for you, as it is around every corner.

content:
er 19, 2014
												Gameplay: Relatively simply turn-based combat, made interesting with many different weapons, spells, items and other variables that keep the action consistently engaging and fun throughout the game. There are also many different types of enemies that help to keep up combat variety (although there are occassional difficulty spikes with certain bosses). As you go through the campaign, you will unlock new abilities that will unlock previously unlockable parts of the map, which encourages you to explore the levels and also revisit them later on. Story: Typical South Park fare, well written with plenty of satire, relating to various worldwide events, art pieces and celebrities. The story has many twists and is deeper than it initially seems. Many of the side quests are creatively designed, with interesting plots and characters.Graphics: The game looks just like an actual episode of South Park, the animation is perfectly done and brings the town of South Park and its inhabitants to life. Each location is overflowing with various references to seasons 1 to 17 and each character/item/location is based on some aspect of the ongoing South Park canon. Sound: Each character is authentically voiced, and often have very funny dialogues. A surprising amount of wit is injected into various minor remarks and it is definitely worth exploring each characters range of lines. As well as the voice acting, the music is very well done, with various songs from throughout the multitude of South Park seasons (and even certain songs from the movies) making an appearance throughout the game. Just as good as these songs is the game's original soundtrack, which is an epic, lustrous score.Re-playability: The town of South Park is littered with collectables and loot, with quests abounding and secrets ever-present in each section. Replaying the game is also incentivised by the inclusion of character-specific achievements and abilities, and will be essential for the completionist or OCD afflicted.

content:
9, 2014
												I'm going to say this is one of the best RPG's ever made in my opinion. Yes, it IS short, be warned about that beforehand, you'll finish the game in 25 hours if you take your sweet time, and you should, because what makes this game so good it's the amount of detail put into it. Rushing past everything would be playing this game wrong, this isn't to be played in a hurry. Actually, the game expects a little of thinking and observation from your part with a lot of puzzles, for example those optional ones to take down enemies without the need to fight them. Even if you're not a fan of the TV series or RPG's in general you'll find that this is a well made game, with a good flow both in history and combat. The battle and overworld mechanics are fresh, entertaining and feel just right. Obviously there is a lot of foul language and even things that people might find objectionable, but that and it's blend of comedy put into a videogame is what makes this one a unique experience you will never find elsewhere nowhere soon, because what the creators of this game took is a big risk, the kind of risk that videogame developers are less and less likely to take when it comes to games of this budget. Why? Because the game has no real replay value, all the effort that was put into this game, you will experience it in it's single run. No grinds, no replays, no hooks. If you're looking for a different experience when it comes to RPG's I really think you should give this one a try.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
13, 2014
												In brief: extremely high quality RPG that will definitely NOT appeal to anyone who doesn't like South Park.In boxers: Although South Park has had several games in the past (most notably the incredibly dull Turok 2 TC), it's only in recent years that the makers of the show, Trey Parker and Matt Stone, have been directly involved in the making of any tie-in games, and it shows. The quality of these games has improved dramatically, finally culminating in The Stick of Truth, a truly fantastic experience that feels like a true labour of love from everyone involved.Playing as The New Kid (who you can customize to an almost insane degree), you barely last 30 seconds outside before  you're drawn in to the Warriors and Wizards-style LARPing of the other South Park kids, joining up with Cartman and (Princess) Kenny's humans to take on Stan and Kyle's Drow Elves for possession of the titular Stick of Truth - which is blatantly just a Macguffin designed to keep the game going.Trey and Matt directly approached Obsidian Entertainment to develop this game due to Trey's love of RPGs, and it turned out to be an inspired choice. The game is an RPG through and through, and a pretty damn good one at that. There are four character classes you can choose from - Warrior, Mage, Thief and (of course) Jew - though aside from the special attacks each class gains, there's really not a whole lot of difference between each one. It's the combat where the differences to standard JRPGs show up to add variety to things.First is the addition of quick-time style button prompts when attacking or defending which allow you to increase the damage you dish out or reduce the amount you take. Learning to use this is not only massively helpful in battle, but it also means you never feel uninvolved in combat, which is a welcome change from the norm. You can also use an item AND attack in the same turn, which, while offering a large degree of tactical usefulness, does mean that combat rarely becomes particularly challenging as a result, especially once you discover the importance of status effects.There's four main effects you can apply to enemies - Bleeding, Freezing, Grossed Out and On Fire. Each of these has its own pros and cons, but once you realise how easy it is to apply them (especially once you find ranged weapons that can hit multiple opponents), you'll quickly come to find that combat loses a huge amount of its appeal and ends up losing a lot of its appeal as a result.That said, if the combat ends up becoming a bit of a chore, then it's fortunate that little else about the game does.There is a surprisingly large amount to do in this game, from finding Jesus (twice) to catching all the Chinpokemon to dealing with the homeless problem, there's an absolute ton of things to do around South Park, which is rendered absolutely perfectly. It really does look and feel exactly like the TV show, to the point where anyone passing by might ask you what episode you're watching. A huge amount of work has gone into making this a faithful adaptation, and it shows.Length-wise, the game will last you anywhere between 12-15 hours, which may seem short, but unlike most RPGs there's very little wasted time here. The level cap is 15, which you'll hit around the 2/3rds point, and once you hit that you can pretty much just avoid combat entirely and focus on finishing the story, which is every bit as insane as the show itself, taking in aliens, goth kids, cootie-ridden girls, abortions, Zombie Nazis and Canada. Not necessarily in that order.Trey and Matt voice the majority of the characters as in the show, along with a few others helping them along the way, and although a few characters sound a little off (Officer Barbrady in particular sounds like someone doing an impression of him rather than the original voice actor) there's a huge number of characters from the show's history on display here in one form or another. There's a few people missing, but then again if they included everyone there wouldn't be much wiggle room for a sequel now, would there?Some people will tell you that there's plenty of replayability to be had, but those people are talking out of their anal probes. There's few differences between classes, rendering that aspect rather pointless, and there's only one point where the plot splits... which lasts all of 30 minutes before both paths snap back into one. Any replayability to be gained is simply from wanting to experience the plot elements a second time, which is certainly valid, but this really isn't a game designed to be played over and over again.Which leads to the price. I can't help feeling that paying full price for this game is really justified. It may be a good game - and trust me, it's VERY good - but on Steam they're asking for £40, which is far too much. It's worth around half that. Also, don't bother purchasing the clothing packs (the 'Samurai Spaceman' and 'Ultimate Fellowship' bundles), as they simply add extra outfits that, while nice, don't really add anything to the game itself and serve only as basic pre-order nonsense. If they decide to release story-based DLC (and I hope they do!), then that'll be worth a look, but I wouldn't recommend anything else.This is very much a South Park game first and an RPG second, so if you're not willing to get on board with the twisted, insane humour of the show then you won't find much to entertain you here, especially once the game really gets going. But for everyone else, this is a fantastic game with few flaws that I have absolutely no hesitation in recommending.Because really, what other game lets you throw a bloody tampon at enemies, then whack them with a giant ♥♥♥♥♥, gross them out, circumcise them, cause them to bleed into unconsciousness and then fart on them when they're lying beaten and broken on the ground? (And no, I'm not making a word of that up.)

content:
er 28, 2014
												I must say that all of the reviews were just about spot on.The game is roughly 15 hours long if you knock out all the side quests and get caught up in trying to pop some achievements. The gameplay is easy, the story is fantastic, and it's just a really well made game.You do get level capped at 15, and on normal you can easily take out waves of enemies.With all that being said I am easily going to play this again and possible again as this is the first game I actually want to 100% in a long time. It doesn't try to re-write the rules of how a game should be played, but it breaks everything down to it's simpliest form and then slightly expands it on gradually. If they do make a sequal I hope there is more to do after end-game, more make the main storyline longer. But honestly it's a minor gripe.10/10 - Would Douchbag Again.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
y 3, 2015
												This game captures the spirit of South Park really well, and perhaps more surprisingly, has legitimately interesting and fun mechanics. The combat is fun, out of combat is fun, the story is fun, and, of course, the characters are fun. It's entertaining enough that you can play while someone watches and they won't get bored (my girl sat through the whole damn thing). It's not very long though, which isn't so much a hit against it, as it was just the right length to pick up and beat in a weekend (along with all the side quests). I will also say that it's not very challenging however. The pacing promises that you will always have more abilities than you'll really know what to do with, money and items come easily, and if you pay enough attention to the mechanics to have a specific build, you will steamroll most encounters (although the enemy variety may muck you up if you're too focused around one subset of mechanics).If I had to gripe about anything, it would be the inventory which felt clunky, and was organized alphabetically rather than say by level (the name of an item doesn't really provide as much context as the level requirements).Totally worth the sale price. Eagerly awaiting the sequel (or DLC xpac).

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
7, 2014
												I finally beat it this morning. I have to say that was a lot of laughs and a lot of fun.  Hardcore RPG players may not enjoy it as much as it sort of feels like it is on rails, but there are still a lot of secrets to uncover.  The fighting system is done in the same vein of JRPGs, but it knows it's other RPGs well. It makes fun of the things you always think about in an RPG while being what it does best. Offensive, Abusive and very very sexually crude.  It's Southpark and if you are a fan of it even slightly. You will appreciate this game.  I personally was not expecting very much from it. I was hoping to laugh, but I got so much more from it. It made me laugh more than I think I have laughed during a game before.  It shows that Trey and Matt really did the right thing by standing by it's side during the making of it.  I have heard a lot of people saying that the game is only 14 hours long. I have played it longer than that by looking for secrets and getting everything I can out of the game.  I have also hear that there is no replay ability with the game.  I disagree.  Reason being.  I felt like i was actually IN Southpark.  I would say it's like playing a hillarioius movie.  If you like a movie. You are gonna watch it again.  If you like Southpark. You are probably going to watch episodes again.  So if you like those things. You will love the game. Those seeking a little bit of challenge I would say put it up past "normal".  There are a few parts that take a bit of thinking and pairing of your buddies. If I had to rate this. I would break it into 2 categories. Fun 9.5/10  Gameplay 8.0/10.   Giving it and 8.75 total. If you are not a fan of Southpark. You might want to overlook it.  While you can still enjoy it. It won't be the same great experience that I had with it.

content:
3, 2014
												Probably one of the better PC games to be made from a liscenced property since......"Beavis and Butthead in Virtual Stupidity" maybe?   It perfectly translates the look and tone of the TV show to a video game format.  Which isn't to say it's perfect, though, either as an RPG or as a piece of "South Park."  As an RPG, the game mechanics are there for a good amount of depth.  Attacks do different types of damage, special moves often involve the stacking of various status effects to do maximum damage, and enemies have different vulnerabilities. So theoretically the game's mechanics could be used to design some fairly interesting fights.  Unfortunately, even on the hardest difficulty fights are incredibly easy.  Special attacks do so much damage that you usually don't have to worry about what type of damage you are doing, to the point that one wonders why the designers bothered implementing the various damage types and status effects at all.  I can't think of a game that would benefit more from a fan made difficulty mod than this as the potential for depth is there in the game's mechanics, it's just that the designers never really tap into this depth in combat design.As "South Park" the game is much better, although it does suffer from the repetition of way too many jokes from the TV show.  This is especially troublesome in instances where these recycled bits come from later in the series run and thus were never that funny in their first incarnation (see, for example, Morgan Freeman gets a freckle).  However, the game does have many inspired moments all its own (a sex scene fight that I won't go into detail over lest I spoil it sticks out in particular) and ultimately part of this is probably due to the length of the game's development more than anything (Parker and Stone canabalized a good deal of the game's storyline in their Game of Thrones themed, three part episode last season, which ended up stealing the game's thunder somewhat.  I suspect some of these jokes would have had more impact had the game been released first, as it was originally planned).   Most importantly, though, even if the jokes occasionally fall flat, the game works first and foremost as a narrative.  The game's central conceit of basing an RPG around kids playing fantasy dress up is brilliant and Parker and Stone are good enough at adapting their story telling and humor to video games as a medium that it kind of makes me wish that they'd write an original RPG.  In the end, this is a solid, if uninspired, RPG despite its gameplay flaws and, taken as a whole, represents "South Park" at its most epic and comprehensive. Parker and Stone haven't tried to go this big, in terms of the scope of the series, since "Bigger, Longer, and Uncut."  Given that the game reaches so much farther than the show has in years, it's slightly easier to forgive the overreliance on recycled material.

content:
10, 2014
												Wow..... wow, what to say? As an established South Park fan I guess I was always going to go into this game with an apologist mindset trying my hardest to love the game; hoping that maybe after a poor track record, like every other licencesed property in the games industry, that the game would be even half to South Park what Arkham Asylum was to Batman. I did not expect this.I ******* loved this game, and was overwhelmed with a sense of dread and sadness as I neared its conclusion, very few games have triggered that reaction. The characters, humour, graphics, animations, plot, soundtrack and general feel of the game were all absolutely nailed and I can't think of a single major flaw with the game. The closest I can get to a flaw is the length, people blasting through the main story as fast as possible might finish the game in just 8-9 hours, those who stretch it out with exploration, side quests and farting on as many people as possible can push above 25 hours in a single playthrough but when you compare that with the 100+ hours of a lot of other open world RPGs it DOES leave you wanting more. However, I'm left wondering whether that's better when compared to how Skyrim and Fallout 3/New Vegas, three of my favourite games ever, simply petered out for me, eventually withering away into boredom and eventual uninstallment whereas I'm being dragged away from South Park kicking and screaming. Die young and all that.This isn't a game for only the most die-hard of fans, in fact the only people I wouldn't recommend the game to are the fuddy duddies who despise South Park and its humour, either getting offended by it or simply not finding it funny in the least. This is not the game for such fuddy duddies. For everyone else though, this game is amazing and completely worth the £40/$60 in my opinion, they could have retroactively charged double and I would still have paid it.

content:
4, 2016
South Park: The Stick of Truth - ReviewTable Of Contents: Gameplay Fighting Collecting Writing  Story Dialouge Conclusion  Final Thoughts Overall GradeGameplay Fighting      While most would believe gamplay and or anything for that matter would take a back seat to the comedy in a south park game, but no! Ive had many tense and tactical experiences while fighting nazi zombies, and nazi zombie...babies! This shows the writers, designers, and programmers came together to create comedy during extremely tense situations (the final boss omfg i wanted to kill myself it was so hard). Collecting     Often I dont perticularly enjoy collecting items in games, it feels random, like it was thrown in to elongate the game. While collecting everything in this game elongates the game from 15 hours to about 18 hours every moments is fun and interesting. I became extremely excited each time i saw the llittle sparkle letting me know there was a new item nearby. Each item was either a great callback to an episode or a laugh out loud joke!Writing Story     Ok. The entire rest of this game is amazing, but, have you ever watched a south park episode because of the compelling episode with twists and turns, no, you watch it for the funny jokes. Thats how I feel with this game. The story is obviously not terrible, but it could have been more developed.Dialouge     HERE WE GOOO! The main atraction of this game is the Dialouge, basically you are paying for a more expansive 18 hour episode of South Park. The dialouge between characters is natural and memorable. Any fan of the tv show will definetly be laughing every 15-30 seconds. Even if you have never seen the show or even dislike it you have to admire the expert writing.Conclusion Final Thoughts     I love this game. I can not wait for the next game to come from the partnership between Ubisoft and Southpark. Overall Grade      My final grade for this great game is: 9/10

content:
1, 2016
												South Park™: The Stick of Truth™ Now that the new South Park™ game has just been announced at E3 2016, namely, South Park™: The Fractured but Whole™, I thought it would be a good idea to write a review, for perhaps one of the most ingenious and epicus Role Playing Games of all time. This review will definitely contain certain spoilers, which could, or could not affect your gameplay's sentimental value. You have been warned. To start off, I would like to introduce you to your character, and how your choice of class could affect the game.When you first start the game, you will be prompted to customize your character. Your character could become both male and female. Now, while I have done five different playthroughs, I still haven't had a chance to play as a female character, so I'm unsure on whether or not it will affect the gameplay or not. Take this particular part with a grain of salt. Anyways, after you're done customizing your character, you will learn that you and your parents has moved into a house, located in South Park, Colorado. After a cut-scene, explaining why you moved to South Park, you will be greeted by Butters the Paladin. He will be your friend from this point on. After that, you will meet Cartman, or rather, The Grand Wizard. You two will have a chat, and afterwards, it's time to do perhaps one of the most important choices, in the game - to pick a class. There are four different classes, these four classes are: Fighter, Mage, Thief or Jew. I usually tend to become a Mage, because as Cartman mentions in-game, "a Mage is like a wizard, only not as cool." But that's up to personal preference. The only difference is the fact that your special abilities will change, as well as a meet-able character, namely, Jesus, will ask you if "we're cool?" There are none other significant changes made, which could alter the gameplay in any way, shape or form. You will still be called a Dou*hebag, and the game will progress, as normally.Oh and... did I mention that one of the main ability focuses in this game, has to do with Frequency Actuated Rectal Tremor, or FART, for short? However, I choose to call it flatulence, because it's a lot more mature.Now to the next part, the story-line. Now, Trey Parker and Matt Stone, has created the story themselves, with the assistance of other people over at South Park™ Studios™. Because of this, you will find a large variety of "inside-jokes", as well as references to previous episodes. In typical South Park fashion, the story-line will quickly escalate, and the Stick of Truth, which is the most powerful relic in their universe, according to Cartman - gets stolen. This does of course mean that you will engage into both the main quests in the game, as well as hilarious side quests, which varies from befriending Al Gore, to getting rid of Al Gore as an internet friend, due to him spamming your email with sightings of the very mythical creature, known only as the "ManBearPig". You will also be able to massacre the Mongolians, inside the Tower of Peace, thanks to the owner of "Sh*tty Wok". You can also help the mayor get rid of all of the homeless people around South park. As well as, helping the Underpant Gnomes getting a total of six underpants. The Underpant Gnomes does also have an influence upon the story-line, later on. I decided to make this specific part of my review, centered around the very mysterious and interesting beings, which finally had their own mission dedicated to them. I am of course talking about... the Aliens. Yes, the Aliens have returned, and they are not friendly. You will be taken to one of their ships, were on both the PC, and the none Australian or European console release - you'll get probed by the Aliens, which means that you will have to break the alien prober... while it's still in your rect*m. The object inside your rect*m will venture further inside of you, and it will become a special ability of it's own, allowing you to teleport to certain areas of the map, previously inaccessible. I will not comment any more on this matter, I'm just writing this of off what actually happens during that mission. Anyways, after a while, the UFO will crash. Despite many small pieces getting spread around the streets of South Park, the UFO itself, crashes into the South Park mall. This does of course lead to a massive cover up by the Government, which involves making people believe that they are actually making a new Taco Bell restaurant, even though the UFO clearly sticks out, for everyone to see. Later on, a person named the "Big Bad Government Guy", whose the main antagonist of this story - will, how can I say this without spoiling the ultimate series of plot twists ever done in a video game to my knowledge before? Let's just say that he sets a chain of events in motion... I will not say anything more than that. These are just some of the things you will experience during your playthrough, and I hope you enjoy the game, because I definitely recommend it, over literally any other game, except for a few triple-A titles, I will choose to not mention during this particular review. Just to mention a few guest apparences from the TV show: My Hankey, Nazi Zombie Chef, Al Gore (obviously), the Woodland Critters, Terrence and Phillip and many more! The final verdict? 9/10, or rather 97/100 to be even more specific. This game has everything you would have wanted from a South park™ game, and everything from the characters, to the gameplay elements, to the combat and even the Achievements, feels very South Park-esque. The only thing that actually bothers me, is the fact that there were several pieces of content that were cut for unknown reasons, I will not mention what type of content it was, but I advice you to check out the original E3 2012 Trailer and to search for "South Park™: The Stick of Truth™ cut/scrapped content". You will not like what you will see. Despite this, the finished product delivered more than expected, and to be honest, I'm more hyped about the new Sequel - South Park™: The Fractured but Whole™, than any other game this year. For future references, I will choose to display the date for today, as well as the current build version underneath this section of the review, because this review deserves a few updates every now and then. Have a great day! And thank you for taking your time to read my Review of South Park: The Stick of Truth. Bye! Adios! Auf Wiedersehen! Chao! and so on...Version 1.0.4 - 23th of June, 2016, 05:23 PM PDT - just because South Park™ Studios™ is located in California :D

content:
9, 2014
												Ok, there's a lot to cover on this game, but I'll just lay out the most glaring feature - it looks and feels exactly like you're part-taking in not just an episode, but in a whole interactive season of the show! The presentation is pitch perfect and all the characters are voiced by their original voice actors (mostly Trey Parker and Matt Stone). Perfect characters aside, the combat is another robust feature. It's easy to learn, but difficult to master; even if you've put hours in it. The story makes you feel both like an observer and a vital part of it at the same time, since you get to witness epic cutscenes and make crucial joices which influence the unfolding of the story. The humor, however, is what takes the ovations from the crowd, but beware - only long time South Park fans will get all the nods and references to various episodes, as well as feel more closely bound to classic characters. It's crude, offensive, with poor taste sometimes, but that cynical attitude makes South Park stand out from the crowd of mainstream TV flicks.  All and all, the game would be perfect if it had been a little more appealing to the newcomer audience, but I urge you to at least watch some episodes before you buy it, prefferably from the newer seasons.

												Let's get this out of the way: If you don't enjoy south park as an animated show there's nothing here for you. But if you enjoy it from time to time or love it like I do, then by all means, buy and play the Stick of Truth. This is by far the most faithful adaptation of any TV show I've ever seen for a video game. It feels like you're playing a season of South Park. A good season at that. The game is a japanese-style RPG similar to Costume Quest and Mario & Luigi RPG series. There are a lot of great environment puzzles to get itens and avoid battles. The combat can feel a little too easy most of the time, but nothing that can ruin what is likely to be a great experience for you.

												South Park: The Stick of Truth follows the story of Sir ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. (The new kid on the block) Who moved to South Park  during the children's "Stick of Truth" game. Without revealing too much, it's a gimic of an old dungeons and dragons game with aspects of turn based combat games. Their are two "Teams" both fighting to keep and hold the "Stick of Truth" They are, The Humans Of Kupa Keep, and, well the Elves... It's an easy smooth running game that, well has a lot of content.Negative and positive listed below. Positives: 
 Just like watching an episode of the show South Park we've all come to love  Voice acting is perfect for all characters throughout The Artwork is consistent and lovely The Sidequests are compelling alongside a good main story  It's humourus 90% of the time Negatives  Lip sinking isn't perfect A few random crashes but nothing major Slightly unbalenced combat at some points Thanks for reading my review! I hope it helped you.

												This will surely be one of the best games of 2014. People may think that is just an overpriced game about fart jokes, but it's way better than that.In this epic game, we play as the New Kid, after he and his parents move to South Park, a quiet little mountain town. But there is a reason for this change. The kid has a power, for wich he is wanted by the goverment.As for the gameplay, it's awesome. We get to freely explore South Park and all its iconic places and see all the characters from the series (and then, there's 16 bit Canada).The combat is way better than would be expected in this kind of game. In the early game, you get to choose your class: you can be either a warrior, wizard, thief or jew. Each class has its own attacks. The combat is turn based and very complex, as we learn new attacks and magic moves and... farts.The story is also very good. This is just an innocent game by the kids of South Park, based on the "Stick of Truth", but as the game continues a lot of changes are made to the world and there are a lot of plot twists. There are even choices that the player can make! Altough they don't make very significant changes to the story (still better than Call of Duty).Long story short, you should buy this game now, as the price of 39,99€ is definitely worth it.

												It's definitely a great turn-based RPG for both avid fans of the series and newcommers alike, although fans will appreciate the satire a lot more. Overall I am greatly pleased with the game and hope to see DLC additions added to the game in the future as there is a lot potential with this. only complaints I had with it were:1. WAY too short (100%'d all quests/ Max level in 15 hours)2. Item organization could be vastly improved3. Classes could be a bit more clearly defined, The abilites are great but with no gear restrictions, you can handle anything with anything, There is very little advantage to playing anyone one particular class archetype.All that being said, it is still a super awesome game and I'm glad South Park finally got a game worthy of the series.

content:
16, 2014
												The Stick of Truth is at its best when it straddles the incredible - but true - ability of a bunch of kids to bring a game of pretend to extreme heights of seriousness, with limited stakes appearing huge.It's at its best when it is about play.In these phases, the succinct turn-based combat, the battleground navigation, the limited character interaction and shape of the world exist as a masterful and coherent whole. They generate this fantastic flow that - in one trick - justify the game pretense while engaging the player in it, epic battle throughout fake taverns and parental curfew taken in strides.When the world of 'normal' adult gets involved or when the game brings back some of the series lore along with stalwart tropes, it is far less successful: the veil of pretend falls and what's left is a giddy but dull self-awareness that highlights the least  flattering parts of the game structure. Chief of these is the turn based combat and its place in the progression: it allows for tedious conservatism (same moves all the time) instead of encouraging experimentation with your equipment and with your buddies during encounters. In the same way, the block system has very unreliable sign and feedback; which makes it difficult to use.Beside that, your mileage may vary: South Park has built several facets during its run and I don't care for the scat humor from the first seasons or the easy lampooning of popular culture icons that recent years have brought.Some people do and I expect they'll enjoy the game to through and through. I couldn't because what really interests me is the writers harsh tackling of controversial topics or of the darker aspects of the  logic and ecosystem that you'll find in a pack of kids. There's a significant amount of that (along with a nearly invisible touch of social commentary), but the scat and the pop-ref ARE what the last two thirds of the game ride on.And I can't support that choice: it makes the game less of a beast of its own - self contained, designed for the experience - and makes it rely on a bunch of crutches that are offputtingly obvious and ultimately unnecessary.The music is awesome though.

content:
5, 2014
												Only having a few hours in South Park I can already tell you that this game is AMAZING if you love the immature comedy that is South Park. What I wanted most out of this game is for it to bring me into the world of South Park and allow me to join in on the wacky rides that Kenny, Kyle, Stan, and Cartman get into. And that is exactly what is going on. I didn't expect the absurd amount of detail that you find throughout the world. It's not just do that quest do this quest move on, really take some time to explore you'll find countless amounts of subtle farts of hilarity. What else that shocked me is how good the combat it. Let's face it turn based isn't for everyone, but I can't help but adore it when you get all these wacky weapons and skills. It also takes some strategy to get it right, sometimes you might not simpily have the right companions or maybe you're too undergeared or maybe you just have bad reaction time and missed a few blocks that killed you. Overall the RPG aspect of this game is amazing as well.As a game reviewer on Youtube for over two years now I've seen my fair share of awesome and equally ♥♥♥♥♥♥ games. I don't know what it is about South Park: The Stick of Truth but it's easily one of my most cherished additions to my collection.I HIGHLY suggest you buy the game and experience the game first hand but if you don't have the funding or simily prefer playthroughs I have started one on my channel and you're more than welcome to join me on my adventure. But please consider buying this game and supporting the wonderful people that took the time to make this.

content:
er 30, 2014
												I really enjoyed this game!  Combat is pretty easy, at least if you have a min/max mentality when it comes to choosing companions, gear, and spells.  Fortunately, there's just enough combat in the game to balance out the exploration aspect without become too overly boring by the end of the game (for South Park fans, at least).  The game does a super job of recreating all the landmarks of the TV show and the voice acting is exactly what a fan would hope for.  I do get a little bit of screen tearing that I haven't been able to get rid of, but it's not enough of a problem to sour the game for me.  Stick of Truth features superb controller support and I appreciated being able to earn Steam achievements and play without launching UPlay even though this is an Ubisoft game.  This is an easy game to recommend for South Park fans.

content:
4, 2014
												SPOILERS: I was a fan the moment I pooped for the first time in-game. Seriously, though... after 5 full play throughs and acquiring all of the achievements, I can say that I've checked out every nook and cranny of this game. It's genius. For me, the game and gameplay itself is not complicated at all, as there is no real crafting or spellbooks and the kinds of things we've all come to expect in fantasy-themed games. For me rather, it is the script/plot, the characters and the environment that are beyond brilliant. As many other reviewers have noted, you are basically in one long episode of South Park. The humor is crude, the items you find are equal parts filthy and "cute", the farts are deadly, and the snuke is buried deep within the most cavernous ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ (pun intended) that you can possiby imagine... I can only say that to me the wait for this game was entirely worth it and I hope that we get more SP games or DLC like this. I will still play this again in the future, as even by the end of the 5th play through, I found myself laughing so hard I was in tears at points in the game that I'd already been through... like a favorite episode of SP that you can watch over and over again, this game is hilarious.

content:
7, 2014
												As for the South Park, and Paper Mario fan I am, I have had alot of fun playing this game. Surely it's not the lengthiest RPG (with a barely 15 hour long gameplay time), and while the combat is rather tame with the lack of depth, balance and variety, as some spells or attacks are more ineffective than others, while you'll find some devastating attacks which will prevent you from varying the way you play, but for it's short storymode it should keep you entertained until you've played through all the sidequests and the main story.As for a South Park game, it truly feels like you're watching an actual South Park episode, or even a whole season, at the same time while playing.Also, important mention is how the game plays alot like Paper Mario, with ''active turnbased combat'', by which I mean every move you perform requires you to either tap a button, or time a button pressing in order to successfully perform an action.The game also has partners, which all have their own unique abillities and spells, like such as Butters's Professor Chaos transformation (which by the way, is my favourite pick).However, if you have no interest for South Park, or even have a certain disgust for it, you won't be missing out at all if you're not going to buy it. A must have for a South Park fan however.8/10

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
5, 2014
												It might sound like a backhanded compliment to call something "The Best South Park Game", but it's probably something South Park Studios would gladly slap on the box of this thing with all the underhandedness that that would entail, so we'll run with that. It's relevant that it's actually the best South Park game by a massive, orders-of-magnitude margin and actually manages to be a halfway decent game in its own right.The plot revolves around your character, the New Kid, moving into a vacant house in South Park with your mom and dad. Within short order you stumble across the kids from the show who are fully wrapped up in a 4th grade LARPing session revolving around the Stick of Truth. You're quickly enlisted to help in the conflict between the Humans, led by Cartman, versus the Jewish Elves led by Kyle.  If you saw the "Console Wars" episodes of the show, they lead directly into this game in a way I don't think I've actually seen a licensed product do before. It's legitimately worth streaming them online prior to playing the game, as the game could really be considered just an extension of that plotline. It's also a fun contrast to see what happens when the writers of the show aren't bound by Comedy Central's standards and practices. South Park as a show is known for pushing the envelope pretty seriously. South Park the movie had something like 250 uses of the word "♥♥♥♥", was obscenely violent, had Satan in a gay relationship with a (then still alive) Saddam Husein, and featured a giant talking clitoris onscreen as a plot macguffin.The game puts the movie to absolute shame in terms of pure raunch.This is easily the most gleefully offensive South Park has ever gotten, and they have things in this game the MPAA would've balked at. Were this a film it would've quite easily landed an NC-17 rating. I don't even want to spoil any of it because it's been a really long time since I've been genuinely shocked by a game, and this game managed to pull it off several times over the course of its 15 hours or so. Just by way of a comparatively mild example: You get "summmon" items in the game in a nod to Final Fantasy's summon mechanic, but here it's assorted bit characters from the show. One of them is Mr. Slave, who pulls his pants down and lands ♥♥♥-first on your enemies before stuffing them inside of him while he moans with pleasure (in my case he performed this move against a 4th grade hall monitor, which means I've played a game where an adult stuffs a child up his ♥♥♥ as an attack. Try to imagine if they'd put that in a movie, even as a joke.)Get ready for a lot of cartoon nudity, basically.It's not all sex jokes, either. The plot starts as a bunch of 4th graders playing live action Dungeons and Dragons but things dramatically escalate from there and the stakes become much more real-world and cheerily violent and dark, even as the game (very amusingly) never loses sight of the fact that you're just some 12 year old kid playing pretend. This is used to attach a lot of legitimate RPG mechanics onto the game as well.You're given the ability to customize your character's appearance, though not their gender -- you're always male. To be fair the game does give a perfectly sensible plot reason for this and it's played up for humor later. You can find and equip new gear as well as "Materia" of a sort (here called "Weapon Strap-Ons" because of course) and as the game progresses you get a series of spells that can be used outside of combat for environmental challenges, like using your "Dragonshout" power (which is a fart, naturally) to ignite open flames and light anything behind them on fire to clear a path.Bosses include the denizens of a meth lab, red headed hall monitors, goth kids, 16 year old girls, drunk hobos, assorted wildlife, nazi zombie cattle, aborted fetuses, and in one memorable instance your father's swinging scrotum which you have to dodge using a quicktime event. Somehow it all actually holds together in the gameplay department. Part of this is due to the game being made by Obsidian who know their way around an RPG and have a good sense of how to interweave gameplay and narrative. The game's pacing is almost weirdly solid, even as it sticks to the fundamentals. There's a definitive first, second, and third act; sub quests are handed out at an even clip; you're given a narrative break after major plot events in the form of the day ending. It has the usual South Park problem where they never seem quite sure how to end the thing and it winds up getting so ridiculous that when it finally wraps everything up it kind of just...Stops, anticlimactically (which the game promptly lampshades and mocks, so). On the downside, the game is really easy, to the point where combat actually gets kind of boring because some of the crew's powers are so overbearingly good. You're allowed to use an item at every turn before attacking; there's an item (coffee) that allows you to attack twice. If you're willing to just stock up on coffee and pound it every round for the difficult-ish fights they become snore-inducingly easy even on Hardcore difficulty. If you want challenge out of this you sort of have to make it yourself, because you almost have to try if you want to lose. It also means that while there's a good amount of variety to the jokes, just because of the nature of turn-based RPG games you're going to start eventually hearing a lot of the same lines over and over again. Attack animations also cannot be skipped or disabled, which gets old quick as the really good ones come with comensurately lengthy animations attached to them. It's stuff that probably could've been ironed out if the game had a little more time in the oven, but if you've read about the very troubled history of the development of this game it's actually pretty wild that it turned out as good as it did, where I have to scrape a bit if I want to find things to complain about.Basically, it's short but it's reasonably mechanically solid, well voice acted, looks exactly like the show, and is honestly pretty funny and worth playing for the jaw-dropping level of objectionable content they managed to cram into basically every section of the game on what seems to have been a dare. Needless to say if you're easily offended or like to consider yourself above relentlessly juvenile humor because you worry deeply about what others will think about your values system instead of, say, reviewing the game in a public place so everyone will know you played and enjoyed it despite said objectionable content, then you should probably not bother with this game at all. If the idea of jokes about abortion, nazis, pedophiles, Canada, things that can be found inside Mr. Slave's colon (condoms, puppets, live bats, a working flashlight, an iPhone, etc.) and so forth doesn't sound like your cup of tea, your enjoyment of this game will probably be somewhat limited.

												What can I say?Its South Park alright and its JUST like the TV series we all love. Its brutal-honest, rude, sexist, racism and overall butt-jokes all over. I gotta say I was ♥♥♥♥♥♥ at first because of the stupid region lock and censor version I get in germany but BOY....I sure as hell wouldnt let MY kid play this game.....no sir......not for the nazi signs but the overall expressions and topic of the game isnt for minors.Okay so its South park all right. We love it and theres enough to laugh about. How does it fare regarding RPG mechanics?Surprisingly its a solid even tho old-school system in place. The items and powers are good for a chuckle and give enough complexity to keep you min-maxing as it "should" be. Whats new are the mini-games tied to combat attacks and moves. Its more then just buttom smashing and requires timing and overall awarness. I m not to the end yet but I m itching to restart the whole thing just with another class.The save system is a bit ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ as you can only have one save at a time. It gets auto-updated whenever you do certain stuff in the game. You cannot save manually (well you can but it doesnt do what we expect it to do)So far I feel like playing and watching an episode of South Park which is probably the best compliment you can give to this game. Atmosphere is great and I find myself laughing out lout often enough to keep drawing the attention of my wife and cats )8/10Theres only minor things distracting from a "perfect" experience. This well is well worth the prize if you are into RPGs :)

content:
er 25, 2014
												Hmm what can i say about this game.Its south park, but also its a role playing game set in the south universe.It took a while for the developers of this game to release it, after having the studio that was making it kind of get split up and sold.  The creators Trey Parker and Matt Stone had a huge hand in helping make this game become a reality.  They of course do most of hte voice work, but also it seams they had a say in how the game characters should move and feel when you play.When you start this game you get treated to a great introduction that you will say to yourself...this is definately south park.  All the way down to when you create your character and move them around it will look like a south park cartoon.This game impressed me alot, by the care and work done on it.  The humor is outstanding well at least to those that like the south park genre and I am sure even non-fans and those who dont know what south park is will like this title.Among other things there is a bit of fan service at places....like being able to see inside for example cartman's closet and see all those things that where from differing eppisodes of the TV show.I like this game and i do recommend at least a try by anyone who has the money and time to play it.Combat like other RPG games is kind of turn based at times.....but the interesting part is that they give you ques to do things during this combat...instead of actual turns.The rest fo the game features puzzles and over area exploration.  Included inthe game is also the silly internal menu whihc they took the time to make it meaningful.  What i mean by this is....you use a cell phone to manage your equipment and friends and things....the funny part is...there is an in game social network where you can see differing things your friends say about each other or things that you do or dont do.All in all I would say this game would delight everyone who tries it.However I am not sure if anyone should let their children of too young an age play this one....due to the fact it does have violence and some harsh language.

 South Park: The Stick of Truth  So in, I forgot I was outside... I have a problem, my problem is that I have little to nothing to say about this game...Seriously, I've had a few games where I've had the same problem. For I feel that they manage to do wat they set out to do, so damn well. That I'm having to really strain myself to find something to gripe about....I quess I could grumble a bit about the turn-based combat system, it feels a bit too standard, run-of-the-mill, copy-paste..Several battles became too easy after I found the most optimal way around them, I believe (if my tally is to be believed) that I died the total of 4-times. During the total of.... 15-hours of gameplay that it took me to finish the game, I feel that's a rather positive ratio.Whilst on the subject of combat, I'm not that impressed by the small amount of input lag I got when using a 360-pad. I've heard that it might have something to do with the game being locked at 30fps, it's a bit annoying when a perfectly timed block decides that it happened a split second too late and this happened way too many times to count.The Audio-Visual style follows that of the TV-series, characters bob around imitating walking, the original cast does what it does best, everything looks like paper cut-outs.. The works.The game has a lot of in-jokes and references to the TV-series and those who haven't seen much of the series might feel a bit left-out, but luckily being a keen fan of the series is not reguired.There are collectables, yay... (HURRRGGGGGHHHH)There are items to use, the same way as they do in other RPG's.....SIGH...Do you know how hard it is to find something to grumble about this game?...You know what? I'l just give up now.. I'm going to Skeeters.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
7, 2014
												South Park : Stick of Truth delivers a true RPG experience to fans of the series, while delivering all the side-splitting laughs fans have come to expect.  The game follows you, as the "New Kid", throughout your quest to make friends with the town people of South Park.  To begin, you choose which class you wish to play, either Fighter, Mage, Thief or Jew.  Players can customize their avatar with a wide variety of South Park / RPG themed costumes / weapons / hair / oddities found throughout the game.  In addition, throughout your quest, you'll acquire a party of iconic characters, from which you can use one at any time as a "Buddy" in combat.  And "as is tradition", everything spirals completely out of control and you will find yourself caught up in a larger than life quest filled with poop, pee, aliens and sphincters - OH MY!  "We want: more... money!""Yeah! More money!""More money from where?""Just more money! You know! Canada doesn't get enough money! Other contries have lots of money; we want some of that money! Hu- how about- the Internet? The Internet makes lots of money! So give us some of that money!""Yeah! Give us Internet money!"Is this South Park title worthy of all your "Internet Money"?  While the quality of the game is greater than any of my expectations for Obsidian, the notorious studio behind the butchery of several games, the volume of content is rather short.  You'll find that you have completed the main quest line in approximately 12 hours, and in addition, a vast majority of side content.  While ultimately, the game can be replayed as any of the classes for a different experience, the experience will ultimately be the same since the story is distinctly linear.  Fans of the series will be pleased with the quality of the end product, but ultimately disappointed in the lack of content brought together for a game that doesn't quite reinvent the wheel.Overall, my experience with South Park : Stick of Truth was fantastic.  The combat of the game is rugged and well polished, rewarding players for successfully completing various quick time events to deliver devastating damage.  The story of the game is hilarious and includes many head nods to nostalgic South Park episodes.  True fans of the series will find that the game is one of the best liscensed games to date and delivers a unique, fun, and exciting experience that many RPG's do not deliver nowadays.Rating : 9/10Recommendation : "If you're a die-hard fan of the series, don't hesitate, just buy the game! If you're more of a casual fan of the series, wait until the price comes down from $60.  Currently, the product pricing is likely only to satisfy die-hard fans of the series who have waited for this game."

content:
ry 25, 2016
												As a fan of South Park I am surprised it has taken me two years since its release to finally play this hilarious game, I certainly wasn’t disappointed. Fans will already be aware of the characters, episodes and outrageous humour that South Park has shocked viewers with for almost 20 years now.  Unlike most games developed from shows and movies, It impressively mirrors the South Park we all know and love. The animation is exactly the same and with the ability to wander around South Park you can interact with different residents, locations and your usual favourite characters feature heavily in each quest.  The story is the usual crazy that Trey Parker and Matt Stone bring to the show - ranging from Aliens, Nazi Zombies and Taco Bell taking over the world and you will find yourself hilariously chuckling along the way. The main mission revolves around you, are the new kid. Enjoyably you create your character in the beginning, don’t spend too much time on this as you unlock plenty of weapons, outfits and features along the way which increase your level and add handy perks which are useful during battle. I was however disappointed that only male characters were accessible during the game, as I progressed throughout the game though I started to realise why this was the case, so don’t be too disheartened. Some girly features are unlocked along the way. As an RPG game this is certainly lacking and is sure will disappoint avid RPG fans. So if you’re into Final Fantasy, then this may not be the game for you. Each battle is a walk in the park and the longer I played, the longer I found myself becoming bored of each minor battle and tried avoiding as many as I could. The game tends to focus more on the fact that it’s South Park and the RPG aspects are not heavily focused on abilities or character strengths. In the beginning you can select your characters “class”. There isn’t any difference between them so seems like a bit of a pointless feature in the game. Each battle always features bizarre and shocking enemies, full of quick witted comments and the weapons and powers unlocked range from farting on enemies to hitting them with a plunger. I loved the buddy feature in which you have an additional character accompany you which makes the game more interesting as they possess different powers. I found that I mostly had Butters or Stan with me, so not sure how that differs from others game play but certainly doesn’t alter the game in any way. Finally, the game also features side missions which are worth playing as this allows you to unlock characters to summon during battles. It also just makes the game fore enjoyable.

content:
y 24, 2016
												This game is very true to South Park in every way. The humor, the plot... everything is very "South Park". The overly-sensitive need-not-apply. This game attempts to offend absolutely everyone. If you don't like South Park, you won't like this game.The Stick of Truth is a simple turn-based RPG. Some abilities and sequences require QTEs, but they are all very easy. The gameplay is very similar to Super Mario RPG on SNES. Pressing a button while defending will reduce damage. Pressing a button while attacking will increase damage. Of course, these buttons must be pressed at the right time, or you'll just make things worse.You play a new resident of South Park. Another young boy that lives on the same street as main cast. Stan, Kyle, Kenny, Cartman, Butters and Jimmy are all playable. Nearly every South Park character makes an appearance, or is referenced in some way.The game is riddled with "junk" items. (Much like those commonly found in World of Warcraft and the like.) You can't do anything with them but store them or sell. Nearly all of them are "easter-eggs" which reference the South Park series in some way. For example, you can find a "Where has my country gone?" CD.The music stays very true to the South Park series. It even incorporates the short tune that would accompany the start of the show, or a return from commercials. In small areas here and there, you will find other music from the show.If you are a fan of South Park, you will probably enjoy this game. It is very easy though. The enjoyment of the game comes primarily from the story. There is a lot of story here. A ton of jokes. At least a movie's worth.Addendum: Why it's too easy. The ally characters each have an ability that can be used, for free, in addition to their other action. Butters' ability is game-breaking. He pats you on the back 3 times in-a-row. This heals health each time. There are item-mods and perks which take effect each time you are healed. (Such as restoring more health or gaining PP.) So you could be healed to full, and restore enough PP to use your ultimate ability... EVERY TURN. Items are too potent. Even without considering equipment-mods or perks. The restorative items give way too much health, and you can carry around 50 minor heals and 50 major. Then 10 "ressurection" items too. It wouldn't be so bad if you didn't find them every 2 steps. There are so many, I sell them off to buy equipment, and still have plenty left-over. Allies can heal all HP/PP to full by switching. They can even use their free-action first. Abilities are too powerful in late-game. Even your basic ability can kill every enemy before they can act. The speed potion is cheap and plentiful. It allows you to take 2 actions instead of one. Your ally can use it too. This can easily overwhelm most enemies.
